support_summary: TDP-43 loss of function leads to the inclusion of cryptic exons, which often creates premature termination codons. These transcripts are degraded by the nonsense-mediated mRNA decay (NMD) pathway, of which UPF1 is a key component.

functions.cellular_process: Loss of nuclear TDP-43 function leads to the inclusion of cryptic exons in numerous transcripts, many of which introduce premature termination codons (PTCs). UPF1 is the central helicase of the nonsense-mediated mRNA decay (NMD) pathway, which recognizes and degrades these aberrant PTC-containing transcripts.
functions.effect_description: TDP-43 and the NMD pathway are functionally linked. When TDP-43 function is lost, the NMD pathway, with UPF1 as a key component, becomes critical for clearing the resulting aberrant mRNAs to prevent the translation of truncated, potentially toxic proteins.
biological_consequence: Loss of TDP-43 → Cryptic exon inclusion with PTC → UPF1 recognizes PTC-containing mRNA → NMD pathway degrades aberrant transcript → Cellular quality control is maintained
specific_effects: Many cryptic exons exposed by TDP-43 depletion are targets for NMD.
Inhibition of the NMD pathway in TDP-43 depleted cells leads to the accumulation of cryptic exon-containing transcripts.

evidence.paper_title: TDP-43 loss and ALS-risk SNPs drive mis-splicing and depletion of UNC13A
